questions.uddipok:
Read the following text and fill in each gap with a suitable word based on the information of the text:

Zainul Abedin (29 December, 1914-28 May. 1976) was a Bangladeshi painter. He had an extraordinary talent and was internationally recognized for his paintings. He became well-known in 1944 through his series of paintings on the great man-made famine in Bengal during British Colonial rule.

He played a vital role in the art movement in Bangladesh and was the founding Principal of the Government Institute of Arts (Now Faculty of Fine Arts) at University of Dhaka. His paintings on Bengal famine are considered as his most characteristic works. His homeland honoured him with the title 'Shilpacharya' or the great teacher of arts for his artistic and visionary qualities. He was a pioneer of the modern art movement and was rightly considered as the founding father of Bangladeshi modern arts.


Question:
Zainul Abedin is considered as a (a) ——— of Bangladeshi modern art. He was an (b) —— of outstanding talent. He gained international (c) ——— through his series of paintings on famine in 1944. In his paintings he showed his (d) ——— and visionary qualities. Even today he is (e) ——— Shilpacharya.

sub_questions.explanation: (a) pioneer (b) artist (c) recognition (d) artistic (e) honoured as l Called

questions.uddipok:
Abul Fazal, educationist and writer, was born on 1 July 1903 in the village of Keochia in Satkania upazilla of Chattogram district. His father, Mulavi Fazlur Rahman, was àn Imam of Chattogram Jame Masjid. He completed his BA from Dhaka University in 1928. In 1930, he did his BT from Teachers' Training College, Dhaka. He completed his Masters degree in Bangla Language and Literature from Kolkata University in 1940. He worked as a teacher of Bangla in Krishnanagar College and Chattogram College. In 1973 he was made Vice-Chancellor of Chattogram University. In 1975 he joined the Advisory Council of the Government of Bangladesh, but resigned on 23 June 1977. He wrote novels, short stories, plays, memoirs, travels, etc. His contribution to Bangla literature earned him the Bangla Academy Award (1962), the President's Award (1963), the Adamjee Liteary Award (1966), etc. He died on 4 May 1983 in Chattogram.
Write a summary of the above passage in your own words.

sub_questions.explanation: Abul Fazal was a Bangladeshi writer and academic. He was born at Satkania Upazila in Chattogram District in 1903. He earned B.A. from the University of Dhaka in 1928 and completed M.A. in Bengali Language and Literature from Kolkata University in 1940. He started his career as a teacher. He also served as the ViceChancellor of the University of Chattogram. In 1975 he joined the Advisory Council of the Government of Bangladesh but resigned'on 23 June 1977: Abul Fazal wrote in a variety of genres: novels, short stories, plays, memoirs, travels, etc. He was awarded many prizes for his great contribution to Bangla literature. He breathed his last on 4 May 1983.

(a) On the way, people were showing due respect to the statue of the goddess.

(b) So, feeling proud, the donkey started to bray in joy.

(e) Saying this, he started beating the donkey with his stick.

sub_questions.explanation:
c + a + f + b + h + d + g + e c+a+f+b+h+d+g+e c + a + f + b + h + d + g + e

Once the statue of a goddess was being taken to the town placing on the back of a donkey. On the way, people were showing due respect to the statue of the goddess. Seeing this, the donkey thought that people were showing him honour. So, feeling proud, the donkey started to bray in joy. Moreover, it refused to move even a step. Then the driver of the donkey became very angry. He said, "You wretched, do you think people show you this respect? Such a bad day for man will never come." Saying this, he started beating the donkey with his stick.

questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions:
a) Why is 21 February a memorable day in our national history?
b) Who is responsible to raise a storm of protest and how? Describe.
c) How did the Pakistani government try to prevent the protest?
d) What did the students of Dhaka University do against the declaration of outlạiving all sorts of public meetings and rallies?
e) How is Language Movement related to Independence Movement of Bángladesh?

sub_questions.explanation:
a. February 21 is a memorable day in our national history because on this day in 1952, the heroic son's of Bengal laid down their lives to establish Bangla as a state language of the undivided Pakistan. On this day, we pay tribute to the language martyrs because of their sacrifice for the rightful place of mother tongue.
b. The then Governor General of Pakistan, Mohammad Ali Zinnah, is responsible to raise a storm of protest. In a public meeting in Dhaka, he declared Urdu as the only state language of Pakistan, which disregarded the language rights of the Bangalee. Therefore, a mass protest started across the country.
c. The Pakistani government banned all sorts of public meetings and gatherings to stop the protest that began following Mohammad Ali Jinnah's declaration of Urdu as the only state language of Pakistan and continued non-stop.
d. Against the declaration of outlawing all sorts of public meeting and rallies, the students of Dhaka University brought out a peaceful protest procession on 21 February, defying the law.
e. The Language Movement of 1952 kindled the sparks of independence movement in East Pakistan by making the Bangalees aware of their rights. Thus, the Language Movement is related to the independence movement of Bangladesh.

questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions to write a paragraph on 'Tree Plantation'. You should write it in about 200 words.
(a) What is tree plantation? (b) Why should we plant trees? (c) When and where can we plant trees? (d) How can we take care of trees? (e) What should the government do in this regard?

sub_questions.explanation:
Tree Plantation
Tree plantation means planting trees on a large scale in a planned way. Trees are our friends. They give us shade and soothe our eyes with their green colour. They give us various kinds of fruits. They give us firewood as fuel for cooking. They give us timber for furniture, doors and windows, boats, electric poles, railway slippers, etc. They give us rubber too. Trees take in carbon dioxide and produce oxygen. Sufficient trees cause sufficient rainfall and prevent draught. Trees along the roadside and coastal areas preyent erosion and tidal bore. But many inconsiderate pcople are cutting down trees for their selfish interests. So, we are losing trees. If there is no tree, there will be no civilization. In fact, the loss of trees will take our existence to the verge of extinction. The earth will be no more habitable. Hence, tree plantation must be taken as a project. The more we plant trees, the morė our environment will be balanced and greener. In Bangladesh, tree plantation is compulsory because we do not have as much forest as we require to maintain the ecological balance. There is no specific time to plant trees. We can plant trees any time of the year based on the type of the trees. Park, yard, urban areas, open field, balcony, rooftops; roadside places, etc. are best places to plant trees. To make life peaceful, there is no alternative to tree plantation.

questions.uddipok:
Read the beginning of the following story. This story is not complete. Write ten new sentences to complete the story and give a suitable title to it:
One day two rats stole a piece of bread. They tried to divide it into two equal parts but failed. Because each rat wanted the larger part of the bread. They even fought for that. Lastly, they agreed to put up their problem to the monkey who was considered the wisest animal in the forest. They went.........

sub_questions.explanation:
Bread Dividing by a Cunning Monkey
Once, two rats found a piece of bread. They couldn't agree on how to divide it, because each of them wanted the larger share. They quarrelled for some times. Suddenly, they saw a monkey passing, by. They asked the monkey to divide the bread between them. The monkey was very clever. He såid, "It is really a difficult task." He brought a pair of scales. He divided the bread into two pieces and put them on the scales. One piece was heavier than the other. He took a small bite from the heavier piece and put them again on the scales. This time the other piece was heavier. So, he took a small bite from that piece, but still the pieces were unequal. So, he did the same
thing again and again. Soon there was only a very small piece of bread left. "Stop! Stop!" shouted the rats. "You are eating all our bread! Give back the piece of bread. We will divide it ourselves." The monkey said angrily, "I have done a lot of work for you. So, I must take this little piece as my wage." Saying this, he ate up the piece of bread and went away.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Rupam/Afsana living at Muradpur, Chattogram. Your friend is Rana/Rina who lives at College Road, Rajshahi. He/She wanted to know how you spent your last summer vacation. Now, write a letter to your friend describing your experiences during the summer vacation.

sub_questions.explanation:
Muradpur

Chattogram

22 November 2024

Dear Rana;

Take my love at first. I have received your letter. You wanted to know how I spent my last summer vacation. I'm writing to you about it.

In. the summer vacation, I along with some of my friends taught the poor villagers the basics of education. In my village, there are a lot of people who have no idea about education. So, we gathered some of them and taught them Bengali, English, Mathematics and some general knowledge. We spent almost 45 days in this work and now we are happy that we have been able to contribute to our society although it might seem very small.

No more today. Give my best regards to your parents.

Your loving friend, Rupam

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Labib or Lovely and your friend is Nishat/Nishitha. Your friend is frustrated about the literacy rate of Bangladesh. Now, write a dialogue between you and your friend about how to remove illiteracy from our country

sub_questions.explanation:
Myself : Hi, Farhan! It's a long time since we met. How're you?

Farhan : Well, you?

Myself : I'm so so. But I'm thinking seriously about a problem.

Farhan : What's it about?

Myself : It's about illiteracy problem of Bangladesh.

Farhan : Yes, undoubtedly it's a big problem. But we have some ways to solve it.

Myself : How?

Farhan : Our government should take some steps to eradicate it. Education should be made equally available for all and it should be made compulsory: Moreover, people who are not interested to send. their children to school should be motivated to and made aware of the necessity of education.

Myself : Is it possible for government only?

Farhan : The literate people will also help the government.

Myself : I I also think so. But our country is poor. What will the poor section do?

Farhan : In this case, food for education programme should be commenced and the poor should be encouraged to come to school.

Myself : We can also help them. In our leisure, we can also teach and encourage the illiterate people to be educated.

Farhan : Good idea. So, from now on, we can do it. It's the right time.

Myself : Exactly. Let's try.
